title: This November I am writing a novel (NaNoWriMo), any tips on choosing publishers to distribute my manuscript? Is it based on genre or is it just as simple as googling? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sorry, this is a Monday so you get the mean answer. Way the heck too early to worry about that. You haven’t written it. At the end of NaNoWriMo you still won’t have written it. NaNoWriMo goal is 50,000 words and that barely gets you through the gate of YA (typical lower limit there is 60K). Plus, you know, editing. Thing is, even if this isn’t your first time at the ball you are going to learn quite a bit as you go. Among the things you may learn is that you can’t write suspense but you really like comedy. Or that you are better at short stories. Or that you accidentally started a trilogy, not a stand-alone. You don’t know what kind of book you have yet. So wait. The time to start shopping publishers is when you at least have that draft done. Okay, okay — if you are mercenary to want to write to order you can research and see what is popular this month. It isn’t the greatest prediction for what will be popular by the time you are ready to submit, but at least you can find out that Dinosaur Romance stories are done and over with and you are better off not starting one at all. So market research? Grudgingly, I say yes, do it. But finding a publisher? Wait.

This November I am writing a novel (NaNoWriMo), No, you’re writing 50,000 words as fast as you can. That’s not a novel. You’ll need a minimum of 80,000 words to be classed as a novel. It will need to be carefully crafted and pleasant to read. any tips on choosing publishers to distribute my manuscript? Hah hahahhah hahahahahah hahahaha haaaaa. Publishers have strict rules on even getting them to read your stuff. I’ll be surprised if you can get someone to read it, never mind publish it. Not only will whatever you’ve written be terrible, but it’s also likely to be almost unreadable. At best it’ll be a first draft, at worst it’ll be quickly written garbage. You need to edit and refine your work a few times before you let anyone else even read it. Is it based on genre or is it just as simple as googling? Google will help you to find all of the specifics of getting publishers to read your first draft. There are several stages after that including editing and formatting. A note of warning: There are lots of people who will try to get you to pay money to get your work published. If it’s costing you money then it’s a con. Don’t do it. Good luck :)
